docs.lead_paragraph: A white couple from Staten Island asked a state appeals court yesterday to allow them to visit a black baby boy that was born to them because of an embryo mix-up at a Manhattan fertility clinic. The couple, Richard and Donna Fasano, say in court papers that an agreement between them and the genetic parents of the child, Robert and Deborah Perry Rogers of Teaneck, N.J., allows them to visit the boy, Akeil, now 22 months old.

headline.main: Visitation Sought in Case of Embryo Mix-Up

docs.abstract: Richard and Donna Fasano, white couple from Staten Island, asks New York State Appeals Court to allow them to visit black baby boy that was born to them because of embryo mix-up at Manhattan fertility clinic (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS the owner of five large Victorian houses divided into more than a dozen apartments here, Jackie Craven finds herself telling a painter how to do the trim on an 1880's stick-style Victorian. Then again, Ms. Craven, a guide to architecture and home repair on the Web site www.about.com, gives a lot of instructions all the time, in addition to answering questions both easy (''How do I fix a dripping faucet?'') and hard (''What color should I paint my house?''). Ms. Craven, 49, has become one of the Internet's reigning authorities on buildings and architecture, a resource for people who want to know about plumbing, Frank Gehry or the Taj Mahal. She is one of about 700 experts at About.com, an Internet portal that offers information and links on everything from gambling to grapefruit. She answers questions from students writing term papers on Le Corbusier. ''They tell me if I don't answer in two hours, they're going to flunk,'' she said. She tells them where to look it up. . She gets requests for house plans for the disabled and leads discussions on subjects like ''Why aren't there more women architects?''

headline.main: Her Home Page Takes Care of the Home

docs.abstract: Interview with Jackie Craven, who runs an online guide to architecture and home repair; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''The Enduring Battle Over Choice'' (editorial, Oct. 11) misses the basic premise in the abortion debate: preborn life -- the infant in the womb -- is a human life, and abortion is an act that destroys human life. It is that simple and that profound. Not recognizing this fact makes the discussion incomplete.

headline.main: Politics of Abortion: The Debate Rages

docs.abstract: Bishop Thomas V Daily letter holds Oct 11 editorial on abortion misses basic premise in abortion debate: preborn life--the infant in the womb--is human life, and abotion is act that destroys human life

docs.lead_paragraph: THE night before starting her new job, Maria nervously spread potential outfits for the big day across her narrow single bed. Choosing between pants and dresses and between a sassy lavender and a sedate beige, she sought a look that reflected the hope she invested in every detail of starting over. Maria is a recovering crack addict. She lives with her infant daughter in a ''therapeutic community'' town house on the Upper West Side for addicted mothers and their babies. Just minutes away are the park benches where she once slept, the addicts and dealers she once knew, and the corners where she once bought crack, sometimes with her body. Every day, as she takes three subway lines to work, cares for her daughter and negotiates therapy groups and training programs, the crack world hovers.
docs.abstract: Article on Maria, recovering crack addict living with her infant daughter in therapeutic community town house on Manhattan's Upper West Side; Maria has just started $8-an-hour clerical job, opened savings account and entered last phases of her therapy; she hopes to eventually have her own apartment and regain custody of her other three children; photos (L)
